messages: 286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:26): Hello, I have a question regarding XML Namespaces
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:26): say I have <a xmlns="urn:a" xmlns:b="urn:b"> <b:b> <c/> </b:b> </a>
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:26): element <c/> is assumed to be in namespace urn:a
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:27): but if I have <a:a xmlns:a="urn:a" xmlns:b="urn:b"> <b:b> <c/> </b:b> </a:a>
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:27): is element <c/> invalid or assumed to be in namespace urn:b?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:28): In the second case, the <c/> is in no namespace
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:28): (which is a perfectly legitimate thing to do)
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:28): ah that's what I thought, but how is it legitimate
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:28): say the doc has no default namespace
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:28): XML doesn't require namespaces
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:28): whatever processing the doc may not be able to understand <c/>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:29): You could write <a><b><c/></b></a> and the <c/> would be in no namespace, just as in your example
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:29): Namespaces don't cause understanding
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:30): they just cause confusion

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:30): I could write <a:axghrlktxjhlkj xmlns:a="urn:a"/> and whatever's processing the document would have just as much chance of understanding it as of understanding <c/>
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:30): You could use the namespace URI as input to a RDF-based knowledge network that would provide all the data you need!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:31): You'd want some kind of schema if you want to restrict the document to known elements
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:31): knowledge network haha

286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:32): okay well thanks for the info, really what i was looking for is that <c/> in the last case defeintiely shouldn't get interptreted as belonging to either urn:a or urn:b
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:33): Yep - if it has no prefix then it's in the default namespace, and the default namespace is only affected by xmlns="..."

286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:35): on that note, what do you call it when a doc changes default namespace all over the place, e.g. <doc xmlns="urn:doc"> <a xmlns="urn:a"/> <b xmlns="urn:b"/> </doc>, still valid right? can't think of a term to search for specifications - "default namespace switching"?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:44): 286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e: You mean when it changes the default namespace in non-root elements?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:45): I guess it's neurotic by the definitions in http://lists.xml.org/archives/xml-dev/200204/msg00170.html
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:48): hmmm... is that post discussing maintaining prefix names through serialization?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:49): That's part of it
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:49): ah got to the neruotic part
286e2543a4c7fb9d8071ff61d45d5a3e (18:49): what is a GI?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:51): Tag name
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:51): ('Generic identifier')
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (18:55): http://www.mikematas.com/ is rather empty in opera
cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (18:57): Is there a webkit guru in the house?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:57): There might be more in #webkit
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:57): cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490: I suggest you just ask the question and someone will probably answer
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:58): 73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72: Which version of OPera, and what exactly do you see?
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (18:59): 10.51, I see only the 3 menu items on the left

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:00): 73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72: Curious. It works for me, although it is a bit slow to load (and has an obnoxious alert telling me to get a modern browser "such as Apple Safari")

cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (19:00): Am trying to build up video demo that, if Ogg video isn;t supported (but video *is*, eg Safari) it will fall back to the contents of the video element. But can't get it working - onerror event seems not to fire.  http://people.opera.com cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490/dev/html5-video-fallback.html Have a brain full of cold so am trying to understand where I'm going wrong
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (19:01): I restarted opera and the page loads now
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:01): 73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72: Could be cache bug or something I guess
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (19:01): but it doesn't pop up about safari
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:02): If you work out how to reproduce then file a bug
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:02): cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490, did you check that error is dispatched at all?
cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (19:03): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, seems never to fire

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:03): 73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72: You're not missing much. There's nothing that says "retard" quite like being a supposed UI designer who uses a modal alert to tell people that a site might not work in a browser that it actually works fine in and that they should buy a Mac instead
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (19:04): and a totallly JS-driven site
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:05): cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490, fwiw, it should be dispatched on the video element
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:05): cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490, also, <video> does not have a type attribute
cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (19:06): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e whoops, will whisk that away and see how it goes
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:07): 73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72: Well yeah it would be nice if the site fell back to something sensible. I have to admit that it looks pretty cool though
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:07): (if it then works that would also be a bug, but I don't think it'll help)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:07): cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490, if you add autoplay does it then fire maybe?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:09): cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490, you can maybe hack around it by checking the associated error object on some kind of timeout loop
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:09): maybe they do properly update that
cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (19:11): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e didn't work when I removed type from video element and added autoplay
cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (19:11): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e hack, thanks, will try. But this *should* work, right?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:16): yeah
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:16): you might wanna file a bug: https://bugs.webkit.org/
cd4b22ed5d04ebb783a3fd8ab0a39490 (19:22): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e thx
